figure_1.title: Fig. 1.
figure_1.caption: Annual trends in breast cancer morbidity and mortality among Japanese women by age standardization on the world population (per 100,000 population). From: Updated trends in cancer in Japan: incidence in 1985–2015 and mortality in 1958–2018 a sign of decrease in cancer incidence. J Epidemiol. 2021; 31: 426–450 [8]. Cancer Statistics. Cancer Information Service, National Cancer Center, Japan (Vital Statistics of Japan, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare) (1958–2019)

figure_2.title: Fig. 2.
figure_2.caption: Annual trends in breast cancer mortality among Japanese women by age group (per 100,000 population). From: Cancer Statistics. Cancer Information Service, National Cancer Center, Japan (Vital Statistics of Japan, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare) (1958–2019)

figure_3.title: Fig. 3.
figure_3.caption: Breast cancer mortality among Japanese women by age group (per 100,000 population). From: Cancer Statistics. Cancer Information Service, National Cancer Center, Japan (Vital Statistics of Japan, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare) (Year 1958–2019)

figure_4.title: Fig. 4.
figure_4.caption: Yearly change in breast cancer morbidity among Japanese women by age group (per 100,000 population). From: Updated trends in cancer in Japan: incidence in 1985–2015 and mortality in 1958–2018—a sign of decrease in cancer incidence. J Epidemiol. 2021; 31: 426–450 [8]

figure_5.title: Fig. 5.
figure_5.caption: Breast cancer incidence among Japanese women by age group (per 100,000 population). From: Updated trends in cancer in Japan: incidence in 1985–2015 and mortality in 1958–2018 a sign of decrease in cancer incidence. J Epidemiol. 2021; 31: 426–450 [8]

claims.sentence: Breast cancer mortality ranked fifth after colon (24,338), lung (22,934), pancreas (19,245), and stomach (18,590) cancer, and age-adjusted mortality has shown an increasing trend since the 1960s (Fig. 1).

Cancer Information Service, National Cancer Center, Japan (Vital Statistics of Japan, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare) (1958–2019)Annual trends in breast cancer mortality by age group (Fig. 2) show that increases in recent years are more pronounced in patients aged ≥ 60 years old.
The mortality by age group (Fig. 3) shows that in 1970, 1985 and 2000 mortality peaked in the 55–59 age group and then leveled off with age, but increased in the 80 s age group.
Cancer Information Service, National Cancer Center, Japan (Vital Statistics of Japan, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare) (1958–2019)Fig. 3.
The incidence data shown in Fig. 1 were compiled by combining data from the regional cancer registries in Yamagata, Fukui, and Nagasaki prefectures for the purpose of examining annual trends.
Annual trends in breast cancer incidence by age group (Fig. 4) show a high incidence in the 45–54 age group, although annual trends vary greatly from year to year.
The incidence by age group (Fig. 5) shows a rapid increase until age 45, a peak between 45 and 69, and then leveling off or a gradual decrease, although the rate has varied from year to year [8].

Breast cancer mortality ranked fifth after colon (24,338), lung (22,934), pancreas (19,245), and stomach (18,590) cancer, and age-adjusted mortality has shown an increasing trend since the 1960s (Fig. 1).

Cancer Information Service, National Cancer Center, Japan (Vital Statistics of Japan, Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare) (1958–2019)Annual trends in breast cancer mortality by age group (Fig. 2) show that increases in recent years are more pronounced in patients aged ≥ 60 years old.

The incidence data shown in Fig. 1 were compiled by combining data from the regional cancer registries in Yamagata, Fukui, and Nagasaki prefectures for the purpose of examining annual trends.
